user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace:
```c
bool
MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (struct MemoryPool *pool,
                               void *block,
                               size_t block_size)
{
  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (block != NULL || block_size == 0);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= block_size);
  if (NULL != block)
  {
    const size_t block_offset = mp_ptr_diff_ (block, pool->memory);
    mhd_assert (mp_ptr_le_ (pool->memory, block));
    mhd_assert (pool->size >= block_offset);
    mhd_assert (pool->size >= block_offset + block_size);
    return (pool->pos ==
            ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE (block_offset + block_size));
  }
  return false; /* Unallocated blocks cannot be resized in-place */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace:
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
#define mp_ptr_diff_(p1, p2) ((size_t)(((constuint8_t*)(p1))-((constuint8_t*)(p2))))
...
#define mp_ptr_le_(p1, p2) (((constuint8_t*)(p1))<=((constuint8_t*)(p2)))
...
#define ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE(n) ROUND_TO_ALIGN(n)
...
struct MemoryPool
{

  /**
   * Pointer to the pool's memory
   */
  uint8_t *memory;

  /**
   * Size of the pool.
   */
  size_t size;

  /**
   * Offset of the first unallocated byte.
   */
  size_t pos;

  /**
   * Offset of the byte after the last unallocated byte.
   */
  size_t end;

  /**
   * 'false' if pool was malloc'ed, 'true' if mmapped (VirtualAlloc'ed for W32).
   */
  bool is_mmap;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace and the provided related definitions (mhd_assert, mp_ptr_diff_, mp_ptr_le_, ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE, and the MemoryPool struct). None of the shown code fragments call or expand to the Standard Library function memcmp, nor do they perform any null-terminated string handling or comparisons (only pointer arithmetic, pointer/size comparisons, and rounding macros). The mhd_assert macro is a no-op, and the mp_ptr_* macros perform casts and arithmetic/comparison on uint8_t pointers. ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE expands to ROUND_TO_ALIGN(n) (no memcmp shown). Therefore there is no use of memcmp to compare null-terminated strings in the provided code; no fragments require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14.
